messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tochibata Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: Bruce, Thank you for the information. it helped cue something in my memory for further study. I had two discussions on Tochibata tsuba while at the Tampa show.
messages.messageBody:
Bruce,

Thank you for the information. it helped cue something
in my memory for further study.

I had two discussions on Tochibata tsuba while at the
Tampa show. 2 very different opinions. Interesting
topic. I think they are more remarkable for their iron
than their design.
I have yet to find any papered to Tochibata in the
past 20 years. The advocates of it as a seperate
school seem to have died out.

Curran



--- bbmich3003 <brucemichener@...> wrote:

> Hi Curran et al:
> I have a Tochibata tsuba that I bought from a
> well-known Japanese
> dealer. It is not papered, but, he wrote this info
> on the bill of
> sale: " The old village of Tochihata eventually
> became Izumo in
> Shimane Prefecture; during early Edo, the tsubako
> of this village
> specialized in making tsuba with the ji as carved
> rope, hence the
> name Tochihata for this type of tsuba" [mine is a
> roped mimi].
> From this statement from him, I conjecture that a
> 'roped' mimi tsuba
> called 'Tochibata' does't refer to a mei of
> "Tochibata", but to
> having been made on the island of Tochibata. It is
> possible that
> there are no tsuba with a mei "Tochibata". I
> welcome all corrections
> to the above.
>

messages.subject: Re: Tochibata Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Curran et al: I have a Tochibata tsuba that I bought from a well-known Japanese dealer. It is not papered, but, he wrote this info on the bill of sale:
messages.messageBody:
Hi Curran et al:
I have a Tochibata tsuba that I bought from a well-known Japanese
dealer. It is not papered, but, he wrote this info on the bill of
sale: " The old village of Tochihata eventually became Izumo in
Shimane Prefecture; during early Edo, the tsubako of this village
specialized in making tsuba with the ji as carved rope, hence the
name Tochihata for this type of tsuba" [mine is a roped mimi].
From this statement from him, I conjecture that a 'roped' mimi tsuba
called 'Tochibata' does't refer to a mei of "Tochibata", but to
having been made on the island of Tochibata. It is possible that
there are no tsuba with a mei "Tochibata". I welcome all corrections
to the above.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell
<neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> List,
>
> I am hoping a lurker out there might be able to
> comment on Tochibata tsuba. I am familiar with them as
> written up on page 58-59 of Harry Watson's Nihonto
> Koza translation of Kodogu Part 1.
>
> I've seen a limited number of these over the years,
> and they are distinct enough to me that I feel they
> constitute a distinct _if minor_ school.
>
> Q1: Has anyone ever seen a tsuba NBTHK / NTHK papered
> to Tochibata?
>
> Q2: Can anyone point me to further writing on this
> school?
>
> They tend to be strong solid open tsuba that remind of
> Owari, are thick, yet very clean. The last I saw was
> identical to the one on the bottom of NihontoKoza pg.
> 59 and sold as "Owari". I suspect the papering
> authorities just designate them "Owari", but hope to
> find an either one papered Tochibata or hope to find
> another source beyond the Nihonto Koza.
>
> Thanks in advance,
>
> Curran
>
>
>
>
______________________________________________________________________
______________

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tochibata Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, The ones in the Koza do not have rope mimi, though the writeup does mention they are often seen with iron rope mimi. Your killing me in that I own
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

The ones in the Koza do not have rope mimi, though the
writeup does mention they are often seen with iron
rope mimi.

Your killing me in that I own another one of those
books you mentioned, but had not looked into it
either. Thank you again for all the help.
Realizing they are in some of my books... it is
like looking everywhere for my glasses, only to have
you tell me they've been on top of my head for the
last hour...

I'm now very certain the tsuba is Tochibata. I remain
curious if the NTHK/NBTHK still paper to Tochibata- of
if they just paper them to "Owari" nowadays.
Anyone have NTHK/NBTHK papers to Tochibata ?

Curran

Since I got " messed up " posting pics on the album, I sent a few
more pics of examples of Tochibata tsuba via private mails to the
interested parties.
May be they can post them on their albums to share..........

rope mimi.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tochibata Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: Miltie-- Thanks many. That is very much what I am talking about. Has a heavy size and heft to it, like a blacksmith or iron worker might make, get fairly fine
messages.messageBody:
Miltie--

Thanks many. That is very much what I am talking
about. Has a heavy size and heft to it, like a
blacksmith or iron worker might make, get fairly fine
finish and nicer iron.

Peter, thanks for the links.

I own the museum catalog that Rich T. brought back,
and it is a great little book with many examples we
don't see in other books. I had not looked through it
yet, and don't know if I would have found that.

Curran

messages.subject: Tochibata Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: List, I am hoping a lurker out there might be able to comment on Tochibata tsuba. I am familiar with them as written up on page 58-59 of Harry Watson s Nihonto
messages.messageBody:
List,

I am hoping a lurker out there might be able to
comment on Tochibata tsuba. I am familiar with them as
written up on page 58-59 of Harry Watson's Nihonto
Koza translation of Kodogu Part 1.

I've seen a limited number of these over the years,
and they are distinct enough to me that I feel they
constitute a distinct _if minor_ school.

Q1: Has anyone ever seen a tsuba NBTHK / NTHK papered
to Tochibata?

Q2: Can anyone point me to further writing on this
school?

They tend to be strong solid open tsuba that remind of
Owari, are thick, yet very clean. The last I saw was
identical to the one on the bottom of NihontoKoza pg.
59 and sold as "Owari". I suspect the papering
authorities just designate them "Owari", but hope to
find an either one papered Tochibata or hope to find
another source beyond the Nihonto Koza.

Thanks in advance,

Curran
